subject: RE: [junit] Junit support for non-standard distributed applicatio	 ns
msgSnippet: We use a JUnit-based framework for system and integration testing.  Mock objects don t give you an assertion API or test drivers and reporting mechanisms.
messageBody:
We use a JUnit-based framework for system and integration testing. Mock objects don't give you an assertion API or test drivers and reporting mechanisms. Those are the things JUnit provides, no matter whether you use Cactus, J2EEUnit, our homegrown framework, etc. Mock Objects are a complement to our framework, but not a foundation.

I was just trying to respond to the suggestion that Cactus is a silver bullet for J2EE app server testing -- i.e., a team building a J2EE app server from scratch, not a team building applications to run on a J2EE app server.

Scott

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Vincent Massol [mailto:vmassol@...]
>
> Yes, you are completely right ;-)
>
> My suggestion was only to use Cactus as "functional" testing (but at a
> spec. method level detail) for the container, not as unit
> tests for the
> container itself. For that I would recommend using the Mock Objects
> strategy (http://www.mockobjects.com).
>
> Anyway, that was just a Â£0.01 suggestion ;-)
> -Vincent
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Scott Stirling [mailto:sstirling@...]
> >
> > Cactus is a perfect example of the boundary crossing I mentioned.
> >
> > Our testing needs are much more complex. I work on an app
> server, not
> > components that run in app servers. One could use Cactus to test
> Tomcat's
> > Servlet/JSP container or ours, and even stretch it to test
> containers
> and
> > services outside the servlet container. Maybe you could
> even build an
> > entire app server test framework on it. But when the Servlet
> container is
> > busted (or not built), the whole test framework is paralyzed. We
> needed an
> > app server test framework that could run external to the server, and
> not
> > worry if certain pieces of the server were broken or incomplete.
> >
> > Scott Stirling
> > JRun QA
> > Macromedia

> > > > From: Chris Eppstein
> > > > To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> > > > Sent: 1/21/2002 10:48 AM
> > > > Subject: RE: [junit] Junit support for non-standard distributed
> > > applicatio
> > > > ns
> > > >
> > > > Guillaume,
> > > >
> > > > I'm wondering if you could be clever and just
> run all the tests
> > > > on
> > > > the same machine by putting the client and the server
> on the same
> > > > machine
> > > > (within the same vm even). Remember that the point of JUnit
> > > is not to
> > > > functionally test the software. It is to unit test it. Try to
> break
> > > down
> > > > your code into small testable pieces. By testing each piece you
> will
> > > > have
> > > > greater control and more confidence that it will work once
> > > you put it
> > > > together. It may not even be necessary to run the client
> > > and server at
> > > > the
> > > > same time if you take this approach; the test case could act as
> the
> > > > server
> > > > for testing the client and vice-versa. These are just a few
> thoughts
> > > --
> > > > the
> > > > details of your particular program may prevent such an approach.
> But
> > > if
> > > > you
> > > > are testing your code from the very beginning you shouldn't have
> too
> > > > much
> > > > trouble doing it.
> > > >
> > > > Chris
> > > >
> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: guillaume_berche [mailto:guillaume.berche@...]
> > > > Sent: Monday, January 21, 2002 8:49 AM
> > > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > > Subject: [junit] Junit support for non-standard distributed
> > > applications
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Hello,
> > > >
> > > > I'm working on a Java layer implementing various communication
> > > > infrastructrure betwen processes based on raw TCP and
> UDP. I would
> > > > like to test it using Junit. However, this requires me
> to write a
> > > > test case which is distributed among many processes which act as
> > > > client/servers.
> > > >
> > > > I've looked into jakarta's cactus, and Junit EE but I
> > > understand they
> > > > would support only distributed applications based on standard
> > > > communication protocols (namely HTTP and an EJB contained)
> > > >
> > > > Is there an extension to Junit that would support
> testing of non-
> > > > standard distributed applications?
> > > >
> > > > I've started designing an RMI-based version of the junit
> interfaces
> > > > where a testcase could spawn one or more "distributed
> test cases"
> > > > running on remote hosts and that would report their
> status through
> > > > the originating test's TestListener. I'm basically
> remotizing the
> > > > junit interfaces.
> > > >
> > > > I wonder if such extension would already exist and if I could
> reuse
> > > > it rather than redoing this from scratch.
> > > >
> > > > Thanks for your help,
> > > >
> > > > Guillaume.
